honour.translation[0].definitions[0].def: something that makes you feel very proud
honour.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Over 100 players competed for the honour of representing the county in the National Finals.
It is an honor to have you here, sir.
it is an honour to do something
honour.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the respect that you, your family, your country etc receive from other people, which makes you feel proud
honour.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: For the French team, winning tomorrow’s game is a matter of national honour.
He was prepared even to die in order to defend the honour of his family.
honour.translation[0].definitions[2].def: something such as a special title or medal given to someone to show how much people respect them for what they have achieved
honour.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Reverend Peters was nominated for the honour by colleagues at Walworth Methodist Church.
The medal is the highest honour the association can bestow  (=give).
honour.translation[0].definitions[3].def: strong moral beliefs and standards of behaviour that make people respect and trust you
honour.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: My father was a man of honour and great integrity.
Her actions were always guided by a deep sense of honour  (=strong desire to do what is morally right).
It had become a point of honour not to tell him about Lori.
honour.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if you pass a university degree with honours, you pass it at a level that is higher than the most basic level
honour.translation[0].definitions[5].def: if you finish high school or college with honors, you get one of the highest grades
honour.translation[0].definitions[6].def: the highest or second highest level of degree at a British university
honour.translation[0].definitions[7].def: if a woman loses her honour, she has sex with a man she is not married to
honour.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: something that makes you feel very proud
honour.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: It was a great honour to meet my hero in person.
Being asked to paint a portrait for the queen is a rare honour for any artist.
The city has the dubious honor of being the smoggiest city in the world.
He received the signal honour of becoming an Honorary Fellow of the college.
As a young man, he had the honour of meeting Winston Churchill.
Will you do me the honour of becoming my wife?
honour.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: the respect that you, your family, your country etc receive from other people, which makes you feel proud
honour.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: The bravery of these men has brought honour to their regiment.
To defend his honour and his business interests, he was prepared to go to court.
Her father fought with him to save her honour.
She felt duty bound to uphold the honour of her country.
He would be forced to restore the honour of his family name.
For him this is a matter of both personal and national honour.
Refusal of a marriage offer is seen as an attack on the family honour.
French people believed that the country's honour was at stake over the incident.
honour.translation[0].note_box[2].headin: – Meaning 5: strong moral beliefs and standards of behaviour that make people respect and trust you
honour.translation[0].note_box[2].sectio: I know Tom to be a man of honour and integrity.
To my mum, paying bills on time is a point of honour.
We abide by a strict military code of honor.
Is he marrying her out of some misplaced sense of honour?
I give you my word of honour that you will not be harmed.
be/feel honour bound to do something
My father felt honour bound to help his sister.
honour.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to show publicly that someone is respected and admired, especially by praising them or giving them a special title
honour.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: He was honored with an award for excellence in teaching.
Two firefighters have been honoured for their courage.
honour.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to treat someone with special respect
honour.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: In a marriage, you need to honour one another.
I was treated like an honored guest.
honour.translation[2].definitions[0].def: if a bank, store etc honours a cheque, ticket etc, it allows it to be used
honour.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Any cheque you write up to £50 will be honoured.
Carriers must honor tickets issued by airlines that go bankrupt.
honour.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to do what you have agreed or promised to do
honour.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: This company always honours its contracts.
honour.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to pay money that you owe
honour.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Burundi was unable to honor its foreign debt commitments.
honour.translation[3].definitions[0].def: the respect that people have for a person, organization etc
honour.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The incident damaged the company’s honour and credibility.
honour.translation[3].definitions[1].def: a level of university degree that is higher than the most basic level
honour.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: You will need a good 2.1 honours degree.
honour.translation[3].definitions[2].def: used when speaking to a judge
